|cpu1_cores = 1 |cpu1_type = MIPS 74K |cpu1_type_rev = (R2) |cpu1spd = 600 |is_doc = |bus = 8-bit |flash1type = Serial |fla1_num = |fla1chip = Spansion;S29GL256P10TFI01; |flash1size = 32 |flash1maxsize = |ram1type = |ram1type1 = |ram1spd = |ram1size = 256 |ram1chip = Samsung;K4T1G164QF; |ram1_num = 2 |nvramsize = 64 |eth_cpu = true |sw1chip = Broadcom;BCM53125;BCM53125SKMML; |wan_ports = 1 |wan_speed = 1GbE |lan_ports = 4 |lan_speed = 1GbE |ethstandard = IEEE 802.3/3u/3ab |portbasedvlan = |802.1qvlan = |auto_mdix = |sup_jumbo = |ethoui = 08:60:6E, 30:85:A9, 50:46:5D, C8:60:00 |oui = 08:60:6E, 30:85:A9, 50:46:5D, C8:60:00 |bootwait = |stockbootloader = CFE;;; |stockos = Linux;2.6.22.19;; |exp_if_types = USB 2.0, MicroSD Card slot |exp_usb_num = 2 |exp_sdmmc_num = 1 |usb_hub = |pwr_volt_type = VDC |pwr_vdc = 19 |pwr_amp_dc = 1.58 |pwr_conn = barrel |pwr_barrel_outer = |pwr_barrel_inner = |pwr_barrel_len = |pwr_pol = |serial = yes,, 4-pin header |jtag = yes,, 10-pin header |specialfeat = |flags = |addchip = |802dot11_protocols = abgn |defaulip = 192.168.1.1 |defaultlogin = admin |defaultpass = admin |defaultssid = ASUS,ASUS_5G |defaultssid_regex = ^ASUS$,,,^ASUS_5G$ |default_ch = |manuf = Askey |manuf_model = |manuf_rev = |is_manuf = No |tpfirmware = AsusWRT-Merlin, DD-WRT, OpenWrt, TomatoUSB, Tomato RAF (Victek) |availability = Discontinued |eoldate = |fccapprovdate = 12/07/2011 |estreldate = 12/22/2011 |estprice = |upc = 886227037353 |ean = |dx_sku = |newegg = |asin = B006QB1RPY |asin_country = |asin2 = |asin_country2 = |countrymanuf = China |buttons = |led = |dimensions = |weight = |wi1_if_name = |rad1chip1 = Broadcom;BCM4331; |rad1oui = |rad1_ant_conn = U.FL,RP-SMA |rad1txchains = 3 |rad1rxchains = 3 |rad1sstreams = 3 |rad1stand = IEEE 802.11b/g/n |rad1n = 450 |rad1g = 54 |rad1b = 11 |rad1freq = 2.4 |rad1correv = 29 |rad1cap = |wi2_if_name = |rad2chip1 = Broadcom;BCM4331; |rad2oui = |rad2_ant_conn = U.FL,RP-SMA |rad2txchains = 3 |rad2rxchains = 3 |rad2sstreams = 3 |rad2stand = IEEE 802.11a/n |rad2n = 450 |rad2a = 54 |rad2freq = 5 |rad2correv = 29 |rad2cap = }}{{TIDTOC|embedded}} ==Overview== Simultaneous Dual-Band, Gigabit Ethernet, 3x3:3 (450Mbps) *FCC ID: [https://fccid.io/MSQ-RT0K00 MSQ-RT0K00] - '''ASUS RT-N66U''' - PCB Rev.3.3 This router is sold in some locations as the [http://usa.asus.com/Networks/Wireless_Routers/RTN66R/ RT-N66R]. :It is also available in white as the [https://www.asus.com/Networking/RTN66W/ RT-N66W]. The CPU is part BCM4706KPBG. The switch is part BCM53125SKMML. :Revision B2 is the same as B1, but have different CFE version. *[[ASUS RT-N66U#Pictures|Asus_RT-N66U]] (pictures) Annihilator666's photos have a sticker on the device showing an: :OUI of 10:BF:48, LAN OUI of 20:CF:30, presumably, [http://git.chromium.org/gitweb/?p=chromiumos/third_party/autotest.git;a=blob;f=server/cros/chaos_static_ap_list.conf;h=96ffe88e6ec025cb32eabb71d13ca12b0b0feb39;hb=dcaefdda36ec9e3c281d70ccabb2ec900efce1a7 50:46:5D OUI] {{WiFiCert|WFA12169|07/30/2011}} *[[ASUS RT-N66U C1]] (MSQ-RTACHC00) • [https://www.asus.com/Networking/RT-N66U-C1/specifications/ Product page] • [https://www.asus.com/Networking/RT-N66U-C1/HelpDesk_Download/ Support page] {{See also|ASUS RT-AC66U|ASUS RT-AC1750|ASUS RT-AC1900}} *[https://www.snbforums.com/threads/rt-n66u-c1.46672/ ''ASUS RT-N66U C1'' on '''SmallNetBuilder''' forums] :Model: RT-N66U C1, H/W ver B2, F/W ver 3.0.0.4.382_19333 :CPU: [[Broadcom]] BCM4708 (ARM); 1x USB 3.0, 1x USB 2.0 :(odmpid == "RT-N66U_C1" || odmpid =="RT-AC66U_B1" || odmpid == "RT-AC1750_B1") {{See also|ASUS RT-AC66U B1|ASUS RT-AC1750 B1|ASUS RT-AC1900U}} ==Links of Interest== *[http://service.asus.com/demoui/RT-N66U/RT-N66U/RT-N66U/192.168.1.1/ Web UI Emulator] *[http://wl500g.info/showthread.php?p=225922 NEW ASUS RT-N66U ROUTER!] *[http://www.broadbandbuyer.co.uk/Shop/ShopDetail.asp?ProductID=11867&Submit=GO Asus RT-N66U UK @ Broadbandbuyer.co.uk] ===Reviews=== *[http://www.foxnetwork.ru/index.php/en/component/content/article/101-asus-rt-n66u.html Reviewed on '''FoxNetwork'''] *[http://www.smallnetbuilder.com/wireless/wireless-reviews/31687-asus-rt-n66u-dark-knight-dual-band-wireless-n900-gigabit-router-reviewed-part-1 Reviewed on '''SmallNetBuilder'''] ===Forum threads=== * [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?p=528281 Asus RT-N66U] - @ DD-WRT *[http://wl500g.info/showthread.php?25929-New-Asus-RT-N66U-Router ''Asus RT-N66U'' on '''wl500g.info''' forums] *[http://forums.vr-zone.com/networking-broadband/1755338-sneak-peek-asus-rt-n66u-black-knight.html Internals and boot log on '''VR-Zone''' forums] *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=86437&start=15 Info from BrainSlayer ('''DD-WRT''' forums)], :now [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=86437&start=216 fully supported as of March 25] ===Other=== *[https://gist.github.com/joshenders/3941269 How to flash RT-N66U with Shibby's TomatoUSB firmware] *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=164504 (SOLVED) Need help debricking my RT-N66U] *[http://www.linksysinfo.org/index.php?threads/temperature-sh-for-asus-rt-n66u.68187/ Temperature.sh for Asus RT-N66U] for Tomato *[http://www.linksysinfo.org/index.php?threads/stealth-mode-timer-function-rt-n66.54449 Stealth Mode (Timer function) RT-N66] *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=165504 RT-N66U cfe - Original] *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=163479 RT-N66 CFE Thread] *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=153609 Flashing DD-WRT onto Asus RT-N66U] *[https://github.com/shantanugoel/asus-rt-n66u-merlin/tree/merlin Merlin] mod of official firmware Asus *[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=86437 On the '''DD-WRT''' forum] *[http://tomatousb.org/forum/t-423607 On the '''TomatoUSB''' forum] *[http://tomatousb.org/forum/t-443361 On the '''TomatoUSB''' forum again] *[http://forums.smallnetbuilder.com/showthread.php?t=6810 On the '''SNB''' forum] *[http://forums.smallnetbuilder.com/showthread.php?t=6446 On the '''SNB''' forum] *[http://zomobo.net/tomatousb-VPN TomatoUSB VPN] *[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FnfdmN-Oq58 ''TomatoUSB (Shibby)'' on the RT-N66U] *[http://md11boing.pixnet.net/blog/post/43444322-%E6%A5%B5%E9%80%9F%E9%BB%91%E9%A8%8E%E5%A3%AB%EF%BC%9Aasus-rt-n66u%E7%B0%A1%E6%B8%AC Label shot and misc. pictures] ==Flashing== {{Flashnotice}} ===Flashing dd-wrt=== [[dd-wrt-wiki:Asus RT-N66U|''Asus RT-N66U'' on '''DD-WRT''' wiki]] {{ombox | type = notice | text = NOTE: Use build 18946, it fixes the WAN port issue.}} {{ombox | type = speedy | text = {{Font color|red|'''WARNING:'''}} The RT-N66U does REQUIRE the '''K26''' Firmware builds
as Broadcom has not released drivers for the non-K26 builds.
(Read more here: [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=52043 Recommended Firmwares]).}} ====NVRAM issue==== {{ombox | type = speedy | text = 25-May-2013: Since BrainSlayer posted some experimental K3.X Images, the NVRAM Issue becomes almost obsolete. Please have a look at the [http://www.dd-wrt.com/wiki/index.php?title=Asus_RT-N66U#Installation_Instructions Installation Instructions] for further instructions.}} {{ombox | type = speedy | text = {{Font color|red|'''WARNING:'''}} 9-Apr-2013: It seems more recently manufactured units come pre-loaded with the 64K v1.0.1.3 CFE and so are not compatible with standard DD-WRT builds. Flashing a standard DD-WRT build on these devices will result in a brick. As it is impossible to know which CFE version your unit has when running the stock firmware, anyone wishing to flash DD-WRT on this device is advised to follow this guide: http://charleswilkinson.co.uk/2012/12/22/dd-wrt-on-the-asus-rt-n66u-with-64k-cfe/ These instructions should be updated when an official build becomes available.}} {{ombox | type = speedy | text = 1-Nov-2012: Fractal has indicated that the NVRAM is resolved and that 5Ghz is working. [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=86437&postdays=0&postorder=asc&highlight=otrw+light&start=1022]}} {{ombox | type = speedy | text = 30-Oct-2012: [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=163479&start=217 RT-N66 CFE Thread] Link to discussion implementing 64K: not sure that this is ready for prime time yet, however, if you try this and feel it is ready, UPDATE THIS STATEMENT and publish the procedure, limitations, and results.}} As of June 2012 there is an issue with NVRAM all but being filled by the default DD-WRT installation. Until this issue is resolved, please know about the pro and cons of this issue, before you install DD-WRT on this router. There are however frequent general news about this issue. If not daily, then weekly news. And eventually a solution to (preferably a 60/64K solution) will also reach the DD-WRT community. As of this writing (June 30, 2012) https://github.com/RMerl/asuswrt-merlin/downloads has implemented a solution, that lives with 32k NVRAM for CFE, but extends to ~60k in firmware. As of July 16, 2012, TomatoUSB, Shibby has implemented a 64k NVRAM solution that lives with 32K NVRAM for CFE See [[#Flashing TomatoUSB|Flashing TomatoUSB]] ====Principle steps==== * Clear settings ([[Project:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|Clear NVRAM]]) select Factory Default settings * Install the INITIAL ASUS RT-N66U version of DD-WRT (file name ends in .trx) using either the Web GUI method or the Recover Utility method. Both methods are described below * Clear settings ([[Project:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|Clear NVRAM]]) select Factory Default settings * "Upgrade" to your final version of DD-WRT (filename ends in .bin) using Web GUI or Recovery Utility * Clear settings ([[Project:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|Clear NVRAM]]) select Factory Default settings ::Note: is '''IMPORTANT''' to [[Project:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|Clear NVRAM]] (to select Factory Default settings)''' BEFORE''' and '''AFTER''' upload of any new firmware. ====Upload Firmware via Web GUI==== * Clear settings ([[Project:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|Clear NVRAM]]) select Factory Default settings. * Upload the''' [http://dd-wrt.com/dd-wrtv2/downloads/others/eko/V24-K26/svn18946/dd-wrt.v24-18946_NEWD-2_K2.6_mini_RT-N66U.trx .trx file]''' using the stock web GUI. * Wait for the router to re-boot on its own. '''This may easily take 10–15 minutes to happen''', so just be patient. * Clear settings ([[Project:DD-WRT/Hard reset or 30/30/30|Clear NVRAM]]) select Factory Default settings. Wait for the router to re-boot on its own!!! May take 10 minutes or more ====Upload Firmware via Recovery Utility==== *Set your NIC card to static IP 192.168.1.12, Subnet 255.255.255.0, Default gateway 192.168.1.1 ([[Project:DD-WRT/Static IP|Static IP guide]]) * Put router into recovery mode by holding down the reset button while powering up the router, wait until the power led is blinking slowly, then release the reset button. * In the Asus Recover utility Access the router’s built in recovery mode by issuing 192.168.1.1 in browser field. * Flash the initial DD-WRT build (e.g.) [http://dd-wrt.com/dd-wrtv2/downloads/others/eko/V24-K26/svn18946/dd-wrt.v24-18946_NEWD-2_K2.6_mini_RT-N66U.trx Asus-RT-N66U_18946_mini.trx] build and upload. * When completed wait until the router re-boots on its own. '''This takes at least 10 minutes'''. * Put router into recovery mode by holding down the reset button while powering up the router, wait until the power led is blinking slowly, then release the reset button. * Flash the final DD-WRT build, could be any of: :*[http://dd-wrt.com/dd-wrtv2/downloads/others/eko/V24-K26/svn18946/dd-wrt.v24-18946_NEWD-2_K2.6_mega.bin 18946 Mega] :*[http://dd-wrt.com/dd-wrtv2/downloads/others/eko/V24-K26/svn18946/dd-wrt.v24-18946_NEWD-2_K2.6_big.bin 18946 Big] :*[http://dd-wrt.com/dd-wrtv2/downloads/others/eko/BrainSlayer-V24-preSP2/2012/06-08-12-r19342/broadcom_K26/dd-wrt.v24-19342_NEWD-2_K2.6_mega.bin 19342 Mega] :*[http://dd-wrt.com/dd-wrtv2/downloads/others/eko/BrainSlayer-V24-preSP2/2012/06-08-12-r19342/broadcom_K26/dd-wrt.v24-19342_NEWD-2_K2.6_big_RT-N66U.trx 19342 Big] ====Simple Instructions (Works for most)==== 1 Holding the reset botton with out energy cable, connect energy cable and switch :on the router with the reset botton pressed till the "on" led blinks slowly. 2 Try httр://192.168.1.1 and now you see the MiniWebserver. [[File:Asus RT-N66U 007.png|200px|alt text]] 3 Klick Durchsuchen und in the Fileserver search the Firmware.trx and click open. (Click Browse and in the Fileserver search locate the Firmware.trx and click open.) Now click '''Upload''' [[File:Asus RT-N66U 008.png|200px|alt text]] 4 When the firmware fully loaded click '''Continue'''. You are back to the MiniWebServer , now click '''Restore default NVRAM values'''. [[File:Asus RT-N66U 009.png|200px|alt text]] 5 Now get http://192.168.1.1/do.htm?cmd=nvram+commit into the Browser and press '''Enter''' [[File:Asus RT-N66U 010.png|200px|alt text]] 6 Now click '''Continue''' and then click '''Reboot''' 7 Try http://192.1.68.1.1 and set ''Username'' and ''Password'' [[File:Asus RT-N66U 011.png|200px|alt text]] If you are not fast enough and the router reboots then you can do step :1,Clear NVRAM and do step 5&6 without loading firmware again. * When completed wait until the router re-boots on its own. '''This takes at least 10 minutes'''. * Put router into recovery mode by holding down the reset button while powering up the router, :wait until the power led is blinking slowly, then release the reset button. * Select '''Reset NVRAM defaults''' when it completes (should be quick), in the browser field, :type in httр://192.168.1.1/do.htm?cmd=nvram+commit. :When done press enter. When complete select '''reboot''' and wait 5–10 minutes :for the router to reboot and start building its layers. * Now you should be able to access via web gui 192.168.1.1 and it should be DD-WRT. ===Flashing OpenWrt=== {{OpenWrtNotice|broadcomwifi}} {{OpenWrt |techdata = https://openwrt.org/toh/hwdata/asus/asus_rt-n66u_b1 |wikipage = https://openwrt.org/toh/asus/rt-n66u |forumpage = |forumpage2 = |forumpage3 = |github = |target = |subtarget = mips74k |arch = |support_started_version = 15.05 |current_supported_version = 23.05.0 |unsupportedfuncntions = [https://openwrt.org/unsupported/wifi_2.4ghz WiFi 2.4GHz], [https://openwrt.org/unsupported/wifi_5ghz WiFi 5GHz], [https://openwrt.org/unsupported/openwrt_only_sees_128mb_ram openwrt only sees 128MB RAM] |image_too_big = |comment = }} Please insert instructions here ===Flashing Tomato=== *[http://tomato.groov.pl/ ''Shibby'''s Mod] *[http://toastmanfirmware.yolasite.com/ ''Toastman'''s Mod] *[https://freshtomato.org/ FreshTomato] {{ombox | type = style | text = '''NOTE:''' ''TomatoUSB Shibby AIO build'' supports onboard MicroSD socket.|image=[[Image:Gtk-ok.png|40px]]}} {{ombox | type = speedy | text = {{Font color|red|'''WARNING:'''}} Requires K2.6RT-N for TomatoUSB,
Do not flash anything else.}} # Set static IP address on computer of 192.168.1.10 # Download the file '[ftp://ftp.darkhaven.org/tomato/shibby20/K26RT-N/build5x-101-EN/Asus%20RT-N66u%2064k/tomato-K26USB-1.28.RT-N5x-MIPSR2-101-AIO-64K.trx tomato-K26USB-1.28.RT-N5x-MIPSR2-101-AIO-64K.trx]' # Put the router into recovery mode by holding down the reset button
in the back of the router and plug the power in.
Continue holding the reset button until the power lights blinks slow,
then release the reset button. # Use the Asus recovery disk and upload the tomato firmware. # Wait until it finish, about 5min. If you do not wait you will brick it. # Power down the router. # Power up the router and you now have tomato on it. # Reset nvram (Thorough). ==Upgrading== {{Upgrade dd-wrt}} ==JTAG-Serial Info== ===JTAG=== [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?p=703880#703880 RT-N66U Jtag] On DD-WRT forum ====JTAG Pinouts==== J2 sure looks like a JTAG header 
1 © nTRST |  2 ® GND
3 © TDI   |  4 ® GND
5 © TDO   |  6 ® GND
7 © TMS   |  8 ® GND
9 © TCK   | 10 ® GND
===Serial=== [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=161286 Console connection on N66U and TUMPA board] On '''DD-WRT''' forum ====Serial Pinouts==== Serial is J1 Serial is J1 
 R| VCC  1 © |F
 E|  RX  2 © |R
 A|  TX  3 © |O
 R| GND  4 © |N
             |T
==USB Info== {{USB dd-wrt}} {{USB TomatoUSB}} ==vlan Info== ===DD-WRT VLAN Info=== [[Project:DD-WRT/VLAN Support|VLAN Support]] ==Pictures==

[[Has images::fcc| ]] ==Notes== *[http://forums.smallnetbuilder.com/showthread.php?t=8259 ''Possible 64k CFE'' on '''SNB''' forums] ==Hardware Modification== *[[ASUS RT-N66U/CFE bootloader update|CFE bootloader update]] ===MicroSD=== sdhci: Secure Digital Host Controller Interface driver sdhci: Copyright(c) Pierre Ossman After sticking in a 2GB MicroSD card and rebooting, the card is seen and mounted to /tmp/mnt/sda1 df -h Filesystem Size Used Available Use% Mounted on /dev/root 17.0M 17.0M 0 100% / tmpfs 124.8M 412.0K 124.4M 0% /tmp devfs 124.8M 0 124.8M 0% /dev /dev/sda1 1.9G 24.0K 1.9G 0% /tmp/mnt/sda1 Contents can be shared via samba in OEM firmware, now to figure out how to run custom scripts from the oem firmware. ====Mounted MicroSD Card in TomatoUSB==== Card was partitioned and formated in Ubuntu with GParted [[File:Asus RT-N66U TomatoUSB MicroSD.png|600px|Mounted MicroSD Card on TomatoUSB]] [http://infodepot.wikia.com/wiki/Asus_RT-N66U On InfoDepot] Moved to [http://www.techinfodepot.info/index.php/Asus_RT-N66U_vB1 TechInfoDepot]
[http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=86437&postdays=0&postorder=asc&start=15&sid=9377afd3cfec250ef362b8ee0cf6fb82 Info from BrainSlayer (DD-WRT forums)]
[http://forums.vr-zone.com/networking-broadband/1755338-sneak-peek-asus-rt-n66u-black-knight.html Internals and boot log on vr-zone forums]
[http://www.smallnetbuilder.com/wireless/wireless-reviews/31687-asus-rt-n66u-dark-knight-dual-band-wireless-n900-gigabit-router-reviewed-part-1 Reviewed on SmallNetBuilder] :[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FnfdmN-Oq58 TomatoUSB (shibby) on the RT-N66U] LAN OUI of 20:CF:30, presumably. This is assumed to be a BCM4706 device. ===Trouble with recovery mode=== [http://www.dd-wrt.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?p=757462#757462 mhchm] I just want to give a tip for anybody who has trouble getting into recovery mode. I didn't find this simple information on the internet yet. First, some context: I flashed a Brainslayer build from a Fractal build, and then my router stopped responding to ping. When booting normally, the power and ethernet LEDs would light up. The same thing happened when booting up with the reset button pressed, which should have put into recovery mode, but didn't. When booting up with the WPS button pressed, the power LED would flash and clear the NVRAM. The router then started up and enabled the two radios, broadcasting a "dd-wrt" SSID, but still no ping. To force it into recovery mode: #Set a static IP of 192.168.1.2 #Press the '''WPS''' button and start up #Let the power LED flash rapidly for 5 seconds, then release WPS #'''Immediately press the reset button, keeping it pressed until the power LED flashes slowly''' #Release the reset button #Point your browser to 192.168.1.1 Voilà.
